questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with paresthesia and severe anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 6 g/dL. His peripheral blood smear reveals macrocytosis and neutrophils with hypersegmented nuclei. What condition is he most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B12 deficiency

 

Option B:

 

CAUSES OF B12 DEFICIENCY: Gastric Atrophy, pregnancy, fish tapeworm, gastrectomy, malabsorption syndromes, nutritional deficiency, pernicious anemia.

 

Deficiency Manifestations: Demyelination, achlorhydria, folate trap, megaloblastic anemia, abnormal homocysteine level and homocystinuria , Subacute combined degeneration of the spinal Cord: Symmetrical paraesthesia of extremities, alterations of tendon and deep senses and reflexes, loss of position sense, unsteadiness in gait, positive Romberg’s sign (falling when eyes are closed) and positive Babinski’s sign (extensor plantar reflex).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Folate trap: Vitamin B12 deficiency → simultaneous folate deficiency due to the folate trap. C/F- all the manifestations of folate deficiency–reduced DNA synthesis, macrocytic anemia, hyperhomocysteinemia, Birth Defects and Cancer.

 

Option C. Riboflavin deficiency: Manifestations are confined to skin and mucous membranes such as Glossitis, Cheilosis, Magenta coloured tongue, Angular stomatitis (inflammation at the corners of mouth) , Circumcorneal vascularization, Proliferation of the bulbar conjunctival capillaries.

 

Option D. Vitamin C deficiency: Includes Scurvy, Delayed Wound healing, Haemorrhagic tendency, and Weak bones. No eye manifestations are seen.

 

Educational objective:

 

The clinical findings of macrocytic anemia and hypersegmented neutrophils are classic haematological signs of Vitamin B12 (Cobalamin) deficiency. Paraesthesia is also a common neurological symptom associated with this deficiency due to its effect on myelin synthesis.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 558-559, Lippincott 7/e : P 375-377

questions.text: A patient undergoing evaluation for anemia has a blood test revealing a vitamin deficiency. To understand the pathophysiology, the attending physician considers the structure of various vitamins. Which vitamin contains a corrin ring in its structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cyanocobalamin

 

Option C:

 

  • Vitamin B12 is water soluble and heat stable contains 4.35% cobalt by weight.

 

 

  • It contains one cobalt atom, to which 4 pyrrole rings are coordinated forming a Corrin ring.
  • The 5th valency of cobalt is covalently linked to a substituted benzimidazole ring forms cobalamin and the 6th valency is satisfied by any of the following groups: cyanide, hydroxyl, adenosyl or methyl.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Folic acid: It is composed of three constituents- the pteridine group linked with para-amino benzoic acid (PABA) forming pterotic acid, which then attached to glutamic acid to form pteroyl glutamic acid or folic acid

 

Option B. Biotin: It consists of an imidazole ring fused with a thiophene ring with a valeric acid side chain. The carboxyl group forms an amide linkage with the epsilon nitrogen of a lysine residue in the apo-enzyme.

 

Option D. Niacin: Niacin is pyridine-3-carboxylic acid and niacinamide is the acid amide. In NAD+ or NADP+, the reactive site is the carbon atom 4 and the nitrogen atom of the nicotinamide ring.

 

Educational objective:

 

Cyanocobalamin, or Vitamin B12, has a complex structure that includes a corrin ring, which is a modified porphyrin ring. This ring binds a cobalt ion, which is central to its function in the body.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e : p 558 , DM Vasudevan  9/e: p 491.

questions.text: During a seminar on vitamin metabolism, the concept of the "folate trap" is discussed, highlighting how folate can become biochemically unavailable in certain conditions. In this scenario, folate is trapped in which form?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) N5 Methyl

 

Option A:

 

  • The production of methyl THFA is an irreversible step and the only way for regeneration of free THFA is shown in the reaction.
  • When B12 is deficient, this reaction cannot take place resulting in methyl folate trap.
  • This leads to folic acid scarcity in B12 deficiency.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. N5 Methylene: This form of folate is important in the synthesis of thymidine and purines but is not the form in which folate is trapped in the folate trap scenario.

 

Option C. N10 Hydroxymethyl: This form of folate is involved in the transfer of one-carbon units but is not associated with the folate trap.

 

Option D. N10 Methenyl: This form of folate participates in the metabolism of formate but is not the trapped form in the context of the folate trap hypothesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the folate trap hypothesis, folate becomes biochemically trapped as N5-methyltetrahydrofolate due to a deficiency of vitamin B12, which is essential for converting this form of folate back to a form that can participate in essential biochemical pathways, such as DNA synthesis.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 493.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female strict vegetarian presents with symptoms of fatigue, weakness, and peripheral numbness. After a thorough evaluation, she is diagnosed with vitamin B12 deficiency. Considering the nature of vitamin B12 and its storage in the human body, which form of the vitamin is predominantly stored?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenosylcobalamin

 

Option C:

 

  • Vitamin B12 is water soluble, heat stable and red in color.
  • Four pyrrole rings with a cobalt atom are called a Corrin ring and the 5th valency of the cobalt is linked to a substituted benzimidazole ring known as cobalamin.
  • The 6th valency of the cobalt is satisfied by any of the following groups: cyanide, hydroxyl, adenosyl or methyl.
  • When taken up by the cells, these groups are removed and deoxy adenosyl cobalamin or Ado-B12 is formed, which is the major storage form, seen in the liver.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cyanocobalamin: This is a synthetic form of vitamin B12 commonly used in supplements and injections. While it is not a natural form found in the human body, it is readily converted to the active forms, methylcobalamin and adenosylcobalamin, upon administration.

 

Option B. Hydroxycobalamin: Naturally occurring and found in food sources of vitamin B12, hydroxycobalamin is indeed stored in the body and used as an antidote for cyanide poisoning due to its ability to bind cyanide. It is converted into the active forms of vitamin B12 in the body but is not the primary storage form.

 

Option D. Methylcobalamin: Another active form of vitamin B12 used in the body, particularly important for the methylation of homocysteine to methionine, which is crucial for DNA synthesis and neurological function. While important for B12 activity, it is not considered the primary storage form.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To clarify the roles and distinctions between different forms of vitamin B12: cyanocobalamin as a synthetic form used in supplements, hydroxycobalamin as a naturally occurring form that can be stored and used for detoxification, adenosylcobalamin as a significant storage form within the liver and important for energy metabolism, and methylcobalamin as an active form critical for homocysteine methylation and neurological health.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 492.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presents to the neurology clinic with recent memory loss, difficulty in concentrating, and changes in behavior. His family reports a gradual decline in his cognitive function over the past year. His medical history is notable for a strict vegetarian diet. Laboratory tests reveal macrocytic anemia. Based on these findings, which vitamin deficiency is most likely contributing to his neurological symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin B12

 

Option D:

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to neurological manifestations, including dementia, due to its critical role in myelin synthesis and neuronal function. The patient's strict vegetarian diet, which is commonly associated with lower intake of vitamin B12 (primarily found in animal products), combined with the presence of macrocytic anemia, strongly suggests vitamin B12 deficiency as the underlying cause of his neurological symptoms.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Deficiency typically affects vision and immune function but is not commonly associated with dementia or cognitive decline.

 

Option B. Vitamin C: Deficiency leads to scurvy, characterized by symptoms related to collagen synthesis disruption, not typically dementia.

 

Option C. Vitamin D: While important for bone health and possibly mood, vitamin D deficiency is less directly linked to dementia compared to vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vitamin and mineral deficiencies associated with dementia are Vitamin B1, Niacin, Vitamin B12 and Zinc.
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency:  Includes Megaloblastic anemia, Homocystinuria, Demyelination, Subacute combined degeneration, dementia and Achlorhydria.
  • Thiamine deficiency: Dementia, macrocytic anemia (folate deficiency), liver disease, depression, cardiomyopathy and pancreatitis.
  • Niacin deficiency: Dementia, Delirium, Irritability, inability to concentrate and poor memory, Ataxia, and spasticity.
  • Zinc deficiency: Depression, dementia and other psychiatric disorders.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 486.

questions.text: During a case study session focusing on nutritional deficiencies, a group of medical students analyses a patient's symptoms, which include megaloblastic anemia and neurological disturbances. The patient's dietary history suggests a lack of animal products. Based on these findings, which disorder or symptom is typically associated with a deficiency in cobalamin (Vitamin B12)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pernicious anemia

 

Option C:

 

  • Inability to absorb cobalamin (vitamin B12) from the gastrointestinal tract and its deficiency in vegetarian diets cause megaloblastic anemia and neurologic symptoms (numbness, extremity weakness, poor coordination, and dementia).
  • The presence of neurologic symptoms led to the term “pernicious anemia” because they are progressive and eventually irreversible.
  • The absorption of vitamin B12 from the intestine requires a binding protein called intrinsic factor that is secreted by the gastric mucosa and absorbed in the ileum, which is mutated affecting the intrinsic factor itself.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pellagra: Is caused by niacin (vitamin B3) and tryptophan deficiency ðŸ¡ª photosensitive dermatitis and neurologic symptoms.

 

Option B. Beriberi: Beriberi (neurologic and/or cardiac symptoms) is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency and is common in those who eat polished white rice.

 

Option D. Scurvy: Caused by vitamin C deficiency and is characterized by bleeding gums and bone disease.

 

Educational objective:

 

Cobalamin deficiency is commonly associated with pernicious anemia, a condition that results from the body's inability to absorb vitamin B12 due to the lack of intrinsic factor. This leads to megaloblastic anemia and, if untreated, can cause severe neurological problems due to the role of cobalamin in myelin formation.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan  9/e: p 491-494.

questions.text: In a discussion on diagnostic tests for nutrient deficiencies, the topic of the Schilling test comes up. This test is specifically used to diagnose deficiency in which vitamin?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B12

 

Option B:

 

  • Schilling test: One microgram of radioactive labelled (Cobalt-60) vitamin B12, is given orally.
  • In gastric atrophy → there is no absorption → entire radioactivity is excreted in feces and radioactivity is not observed in liver region.
  • In nutritional deficiency → there is enhanced absorption → radioactivity is noted in the liver region and very little excretion in feces.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Histidine load test or FIGLU excretion test: Histidine is metabolized to formimino glutamic acid (FIGLU) from which formimino group is removed by THFA. Hence in folate deficiency, FIGLU is excreted in urine.

 

Option C. In thiamine deficiency, Erythrocyte transketolase activity is reduced which is the earliest manifestation before the clinical manifestations.

 

Option D. Dark adaptation test is the time required to adapt the eye to see objects in dim light and it is increased in vitamin A deficiency.

 

Educational objective:

 

The Schilling test is a diagnostic procedure used to determine vitamin B12 (cobalamin) absorption and deficiency. It involves the oral administration of radiolabeled vitamin B12 and measuring its excretion in the urine to assess the body's ability to absorb it effectively. This test has historically been important for diagnosing conditions like pernicious anemia, which is associated with poor vitamin B12 absorption.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 494.

questions.text: Considering the natural dietary sources of vitamin B12, which of the following is known to contain the highest levels of this essential nutrient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Animal products

 

Option A:

 

  • Vitamin B12 is found only in foods of animal origin and there are no plant sources.
  • So, strict vegetarians (vegans) are at risk of developing B12 deficiency.
  • Liver is the richest source.
  • Curd is a good source, because lactobacillus can synthesize B12.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Green leafy vegetables: While nutritious for many reasons, green leafy vegetables are not a significant source of vitamin B12.

 

Option C. Roots & tubers: These are also not notable sources of vitamin B12.

 

Option D. Sunlight: Sunlight is essential for the synthesis of vitamin D in the skin but does not provide vitamin B12.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The animal products are the primary natural sources of vitamin B12, an essential nutrient for nerve function and the production of red blood cells. This knowledge is crucial for dietary planning, especially for vegetarians and vegans, who may need to seek alternative sources of vitamin B12, such as fortified foods or supplements, to maintain adequate levels.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 494.

choices.text: A and R both are right but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is wrong but R is a right statement
A as well as R are right and R is a correct explanation of A
A and R both are wrong

questions.text:
In a discussion on the management of macrocytic anemia, a clinical instructor emphasizes the importance of differentiating between folate and vitamin B12 deficiencies due to their treatment implications. The instructor presents the following assertion and reasoning:

 

Assertion(A): Folic acid and vitamin B12 are always given in combination to patients.

 

Reasoning(R): Folic acid alone should not be given in patients with macrocytic anemia, as it may aggravate the neurological manifestations.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A as well as R are right and R is a correct explanation of A

 

Explanation:

 

Based on the provided information, both the assertion and the reasoning are correct, and the reasoning correctly explains the assertion. Folic acid alone should not be given in cases of macrocytic anemia without first ruling out vitamin B12 deficiency due to the risk of exacerbating neurological complications associated with B12 deficiency. As a precaution and to address both potential deficiencies, folic acid and vitamin B12 are often administered together to patients with macrocytic anemia, making the assertion and the reasoning accurate and related.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Therapeutic dose is 1 mg /day of folic acid given orally.
  • Folic acid alone should not be given in macrocytic anemia, as it may aggravate the neurological manifestation of B12 deficiency.
  • So, folic acid and vitamin B12 are always given in combination to the patients.
  • Regular supplementation of folic acid will reduce the incidence of birth defects, cardiovascular diseases and cancers.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 490,494.

questions.text: A pediatrician is evaluating a child with developmental delays and unusual metabolic findings. The child's metabolic profile reveals elevated levels of methylmalonic acid in the urine. The pediatrician is considering which vitamin deficiency could be contributing to these metabolic abnormalities. Which vitamin deficiency is most commonly associated with methylmalonic aciduria?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B12

 

Option A:

 

  • D-Methyl malonyl CoA is formed from propionyl CoA → converted to L form by a racemase → isomerized by methylmalonyl CoA mutase (containing Ado-B12) to succinyl CoA → enters TCA cycle. 
  • In B12 deficiency, methylmalonyl CoA accumulates → methyl malonic aciduria.

 

 

  • The metabolism of odd chain fatty acids such as valine, isoleucine, methionine and threonine leads to the production of methylmalonyl CoA.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Vitamin B6: While important for amino acid metabolism, vitamin B6 deficiency is not typically associated with elevated methylmalonic acid levels.

 

Option C. Vitamin C: Deficiency primarily leads to scurvy, characterized by symptoms like bleeding gums and poor wound healing, not methylmalonic aciduria.

 

Option D. Folic acid: Involved in nucleotide synthesis and amino acid metabolism, folic acid deficiency can lead to megaloblastic anemia but is not directly linked to methylmalonic aciduria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methylmalonic aciduria is commonly associated with vitamin B12 (cobalamin) deficiency. Vitamin B12 is a cofactor for the enzyme methylmalonyl-CoA mutase, which converts methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA in the metabolism of certain amino acids and fatty acids. A deficiency in vitamin B12 leads to the accumulation of methylmalonic acid, which is then excreted in the urine.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 493.

questions.text: In a case study discussion about diagnosing vitamin deficiencies, a 42-year-old female patient presents with fatigue, lethargy, tingling in her extremities, macrocytic anemia, and elevated homocysteine levels. The clinical team is considering the differential diagnosis based on these symptoms and laboratory findings. Given the elevated homocysteine levels and the presentation, which additional metabolite elevation would support a specific vitamin deficiency diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Methylmalonic acid

 

Option C:

 

  • The patient has symptoms of vitamin B12 deficiency.
  • The macrocytic anemia is due to a lack of precursors for DNA synthesis in the RBCs precursors due to the B12 deficiency.
  • The numbness and tingling in patients is due to hypomethylation in the nervous system because of B12 deficiency.
  • Vitamin B12 is involved in the conversion of homocysteine to methionine, requiring N5-methyl THF and in the conversion of L-methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl CoA and in B12 deficiency neither of these reactions takes placeà accumulation of homocysteine and methylmalonic acid in the circulation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acetic acid: While a common metabolic intermediate, acetic acid elevation is not specifically associated with vitamin B12 deficiency or the clinical presentation described.

 

Option B. Ketone bodies: Elevated in conditions of increased fat metabolism, such as fasting, ketogenic diets, or diabetes, but not specifically related to vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

Option D. Propionic acid: While propionic acidemia is a metabolic disorder, its elevation is not typically associated with vitamin B12 deficiency or the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Elevated methylmalonic acid levels, in conjunction with macrocytic anemia and elevated homocysteine, strongly suggest a vitamin B12 deficiency. This specific metabolic marker aids in differentiating vitamin B12 deficiency from folate deficiency, especially in the context of neurological symptoms and macrocytic anemia.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 493.
